Mercury.name: Mercury
Mercury.funFact: Imagine a world with no atmosphere where one moment you're freezing solid and the next you're hot enough to melt a bucket of lead! Mercury has the most extreme temperature swings in the entire solar system.

Venus.name: Venus
Venus.funFact: Talk about a slow day! On Venus, a single day lasts longer than an entire year. Plus, it spins backward, making it the rebellious oddball of our solar system.

Earth.name: Earth
Earth.funFact: Earth is the ultimate oasis! It's the only place we know of in the entire universe that has liquid water on its surface, and the only confirmed home to life. Pretty special, huh?

Mars.name: Mars
Mars.funFact: Mars is home to a true monster of a volcano! Olympus Mons is so massive it's three times taller than Mount Everest and could cover the entire state of Arizona.

Jupiter.name: Jupiter
Jupiter.funFact: Jupiter's most famous feature is a swirling storm called the Great Red Spot. It's been raging for over 400 years and is so huge that three Earths could fit inside it with room to spare!

Saturn.name: Saturn
Saturn.funFact: Believe it or not, if you could find a bathtub big enough, Saturn would actually float! This gas giant is so light and fluffy it's less dense than water.

Uranus.name: Uranus
Uranus.funFact: Uranus is a true maverick, rotating on its side like a rolling bowling ball! This 98-degree tilt makes it unique among all the planets, likely the result of a massive, ancient collision.

Neptune.name: Neptune
Neptune.funFact: Don't let Neptune's distance fool you. This planet has the fastest winds in the solar system, howling at over 2,100 km/h. That's a storm you wouldn't want to get caught in!

Sun.name: The Sun
Sun.funFact: Our Sun is a true powerhouse! It holds an astonishing 99.86% of the solar system's total mass and converts a mind-boggling 4 million tons of matter into energy every single second. Now that's a star!

Moon.name: The Moon
Moon.funFact: Our Moon is playing a slow-motion game of hide-and-seek! It always shows us the same face, and it's slowly but surely moving away from Earth at about 3.8 centimeters every year.

Phobos.name: Phobos
Phobos.funFact: Phobos is in a hurry! This little moon whips around Mars so fast that it rises in the west and sets in the east, completing three full orbits in just one Martian day.

Deimos.name: Deimos
Deimos.funFact: Deimos is so tiny that if you had a strong arm, you could throw a baseball and send it into orbit around the moon itself! It’s the ultimate zero-gravity home run.

Io.name: Io
Io.funFact: Io is the ultimate volcanic hellscape! With over 400 active volcanoes, it's the most volcanically active place in our solar system. These volcanoes can even shoot sulfur plumes 500 kilometers high!

Europa.name: Europa
Europa.funFact: Beneath Europa's cracked, icy shell lies a massive secret: a subsurface ocean containing more than double the amount of water found in all of Earth's oceans combined! It's a prime target in the search for extraterrestrial life.

Ganymede.name: Ganymede
Ganymede.funFact: Ganymede is a true giant! It's the largest moon in our solar system—bigger than the planet Mercury—and it even has its own magnetic field and aurora, just like a planet.

Callisto.name: Callisto
Callisto.funFact: Callisto is the solar system's punching bag, covered in more craters than any other object! But beneath its scarred, ancient surface, scientists think there might be a hidden subsurface ocean.

Titan.name: Titan
Titan.funFact: On Titan, the rivers and lakes are filled with liquid methane and ethane, not water! Its super-dense atmosphere is so thick that you could actually fly through it just by strapping some wings to your arms.

Rhea.name: Rhea
Rhea.funFact: Could a moon have its own rings? Scientists think so! There's a strong possibility that Saturn's moon Rhea has a ring system, which would make it the first moon ever discovered with rings.

Titania.name: Titania
Titania.funFact: Uranus's largest moon, Titania, is a world of colossal canyons! Its surface is carved with massive fault systems that stretch for over 1,000 kilometers, creating a dramatic, fractured landscape.

Oberon.name: Oberon
Oberon.funFact: Oberon is named after Shakespeare's fairy king, and this moon has a mystery all its own: a strange, dark material covers the floors of its craters, making for a truly otherworldly sight.

Triton.name: Triton
Triton.funFact: Neptune's moon Triton is a true rebel, orbiting backward against its planet's rotation. It's also a world of icy wonders, with nitrogen geysers that erupt spectacularly, shooting plumes of gas 8 kilometers high!
